entry.title: Generic items
entry.content:
These are the things that don’t quite fit into other groupings.

One of the nice things about markup languages is the ability to have inline markup. This makes the presentation much nicer. The bold text shouldn’t be too overbearing. It is very common to have inline code as well. It is important to ensure that the inline code doesn’t have a line height that is greater than the regular prose; otherwise the spacing looks weird.
entry.summary: These are the things that don’t quite fit into other groupings.One of the nice things about markup languages is the ability to have inline markup. It is important to ensure that the inline code doesn’t have a line height that is greater than the regular prose; otherwise the spacing looks weird.EXAMPLE

entry.title: Jupyter Notebooks
entry.content: This notebook is a demonstration of directly-parsing Jupyter Notebooks into Sphinx using the MyST parser.
entry.summary: Open In ColabThis notebook is a demonstration of directly-parsing Jupyter Notebooks into Sphinx using the MyST parser.Open In Colab

entry.title: Building a simple timeline with sphinx-panels
entry.content:
One of the nice things about MyST Markdown is that it is extensible. Any Sphinx extension will work with MyST Markdown (in the context of Jupyter Book, anyway).

One of my favorite Sphinx extensions is Sphinx Panels, this brings you flexible UI components that use Bootstrap CSS under the hood (though without heavy javascript). They let you do things like this:
